title: ‘Landslide’: Santana beats out Baker, Wu says, while Culpepper wins D7
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Rev. Miniard Culpepper wins District 7 Boston City Council seat, defeating Said Ahmed, with a reported 500-vote lead.
Henry Santana, incumbent at-large City Councilor, secures reelection, outperforming former Councilor Frank Baker.
All incumbent district councilors in Boston are reelected, maintaining their positions against challengers in the recent election.

title: Jake Wilson to be Somerville’s next mayor, unofficial results show
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Jake Wilson secures Somerville mayoral position with 11,185 votes, defeating opponent Willie Burnley Jr., who received 9,054 votes.
Wilson's campaign focused on improving city services, tackling housing, street safety, and rodent issues in Somerville.
As mayor, Wilson plans to address the homelessness crisis, open drug use, and enhance public safety in the city.

title: Lowell police seeking public’s help with details about fatal hit-and-run
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Lowell police urge public for information about an Oct. 30 fatal hit-and-run on Chelmsford Street.
The identified vehicle linked to the incident fled after striking a woman, later pronounced dead at a hospital.
Police are collaborating with the Middlesex District Attorney's office for the ongoing investigation.

title: ‘This is just the beginning’: Nonbinding Israel divestment ballot question passes in Somerville
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Question 3 in Somerville passed with 55.7% support, urging divestment from companies accused of supporting Israeli actions in Palestine.
The ballot question, initiated by Somerville for Palestine, faced legal challenges but was allowed by Middlesex Superior Court.
Somerville United Against Discrimination opposed the measure, citing community division concerns and challenging the narrative it promotes.

title: Tom Brady just revealed that his dog Junie is a clone of Lua, his deceased furry friend
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Tom Brady revealed his dog Junie is a clone of his deceased dog Lua, created using Colossal Biosciences' technology.
Brady invested in Colossal Biosciences, which used a blood sample from Lua to clone her, resulting in Junie.
Colossal Biosciences announced it acquired Viagen, a leading animal cloning company, enhancing its cloning capabilities.

title: Running unopposed, Michelle Wu secures second term as her national profile grows
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Michelle Wu secured her second term as Boston Mayor after running unopposed in the election.
Wu won overwhelmingly with more than 30,000 votes and 91.10% of the vote with 44% reported.
Wu, a national Democratic voice, gained recognition for advocating Boston's sanctuary policies to Congress.

title: Tell us: What should Mayor Wu focus on in her second term?
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Mayor Michelle Wu is virtually guaranteed a second term, having run unopposed in Boston's 2025 election.
Housing affordability and climate resilience have been key focuses of Wu's first term, with mixed results.
Public safety and immigration policies are potential priorities for Wu's upcoming four-year term as Mayor.

title: ‘This is kidnapping — plain and simple’: ICE arrests 9 employees at Allston car wash
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Nine employees with work permits were detained by ICE during a raid at Allston Car Wash on Tuesday morning.
The car wash manager stated employees were detained before they could retrieve documents due to a language barrier.
Boston City Councilor Liz Breadon condemned the raid, calling it 'kidnapping' and criticized ICE's actions.

title: Patriots opt to stand pat at trade deadline
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The New England Patriots did not make any trades by the NFL deadline, sticking with their current roster.
The Patriots have a record of 7-2, opting for a long-term team-building strategy under coach Mike Vrabel.
New England traded away Keion White and Kyle Dugger prior to the deadline, affecting their defensive depth.

title: Amid SNAP benefit cuts, these Greater Boston food businesses are here to help
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Greater Boston food businesses are responding to SNAP cuts and government shutdown by providing free meals and community resources.
Several restaurants and stores, like American Flatbread and Seoul Kitchen, offer specific deals or free meals to SNAP recipients.
Allandale Farm in Brookline starts a free farmers market with partners to support those affected by SNAP benefit disruptions.
